_metadata.description: Ancient individual genomes for genetic matching
sources: Published ancient DNA studies with PMID citations
_metadata.note: SNP calls from published ancient DNA studies. Missing data indicated by null.

cheddar_man.name: Cheddar Man
cheddar_man.description: Britain's oldest complete human skeleton with preserved DNA. Remarkably, he had dark to black skin, blue eyes, and dark curly hair - challenging assumptions about ancient Britons.
cheddar_man.significance: First ancient Briton with full genome sequenced. Showed that light skin evolved later in Europe than previously thought.
cheddar_man.paper: Brace et al. 2019 - Population Replacement in Early Neolithic Britain

loschbour.name: Loschbour
loschbour.description: One of the most complete Mesolithic genomes from continental Europe. Like Cheddar Man, showed dark skin and blue eyes.
loschbour.significance: Key reference genome for Western Hunter-Gatherer ancestry in modern Europeans.
loschbour.paper: Lazaridis et al. 2014 - Ancient human genomes suggest three ancestral populations

la_brana_1.name: La Braña 1
la_brana_1.description: Mesolithic hunter-gatherer from northern Spain. First ancient European confirmed to have blue eyes with dark skin.
la_brana_1.significance: Provided early evidence that blue eyes evolved before light skin in Europe.
la_brana_1.paper: Olalde et al. 2014 - Derived immune and ancestral pigmentation alleles in a 7,000-year-old Mesolithic European

la_brana_2.name: La Braña 2
la_brana_2.description: Second individual from the La Braña cave site, contemporary with La Braña 1.

otzi.name: Ötzi the Iceman
otzi.site: Ötztal Alps, South Tyrol, Italy/Austria border
otzi.culture_name: Late Neolithic / Early Copper Age Farmer
otzi.description: The world's most famous natural mummy. A Copper Age man who died in the Alps, preserved by ice. His genome shows ancestry from Neolithic farmers with some admixture.
otzi.significance: First ancient human genome sequenced (2012). Revealed details about Neolithic farmer genetics and health.
otzi.paper: Keller et al. 2012 - New insights into the Tyrolean Iceman's origin and phenotype

barcin_farmer.name: Barcın Farmer (BAR25)
barcin_farmer.description: Early farmer from Anatolia, representing the source population that spread agriculture to Europe.
barcin_farmer.significance: Key reference for understanding the genetic origins of European Neolithic farmers.
barcin_farmer.paper: Mathieson et al. 2015 - Genome-wide patterns of selection in 230 ancient Eurasians

stuttgart_lbk.name: Stuttgart LBK Farmer
stuttgart_lbk.description: Early farmer from the Linear Pottery Culture, the first farming culture in Central Europe.
stuttgart_lbk.significance: Shows that early Central European farmers were genetically similar to Anatolian farmers.

yamnaya_samara.name: Yamnaya Samara (I0357)
yamnaya_samara.description: Representative of the Yamnaya culture from the Pontic-Caspian steppe. These Bronze Age pastoralists massively migrated into Europe around 3000 BCE.
yamnaya_samara.significance: Key reference for Steppe ancestry in modern Europeans. Likely spoke Proto-Indo-European.
yamnaya_samara.paper: Haak et al. 2015 - Massive migration from the steppe was a source for Indo-European languages in Europe

yamnaya_kalmykia.name: Yamnaya Kalmykia (RISE552)
yamnaya_kalmykia.description: Yamnaya individual from the southern steppe region.

bell_beaker_britain.name: Bell Beaker Britain (I2565)
bell_beaker_britain.description: Bronze Age individual from near Stonehenge, part of the Bell Beaker migration that replaced ~90% of British ancestry.
bell_beaker_britain.significance: Represents the population that transformed Britain's genetics during the Bronze Age.
bell_beaker_britain.paper: Olalde et al. 2018 - The Beaker phenomenon and the genomic transformation of northwest Europe

bell_beaker_netherlands.name: Bell Beaker Netherlands (I5748)
bell_beaker_netherlands.description: Bell Beaker individual from the Netherlands showing typical Steppe-derived ancestry.

bell_beaker_iberia.name: Bell Beaker Iberia (I4246)
bell_beaker_iberia.site: Camino de las Yeseras, Madrid, Spain
bell_beaker_iberia.description: Bell Beaker from Iberia, showing the cultural spread occurred before full genetic replacement in southern Europe.

corded_ware_germany.name: Corded Ware Germany (I0104)
corded_ware_germany.description: Representative of the Corded Ware culture, closely related to Yamnaya and ancestral to many northern European populations.
corded_ware_germany.significance: Shows the early spread of Steppe ancestry into Central Europe.

corded_ware_baltic.name: Corded Ware Baltic (RISE00)
corded_ware_baltic.description: Corded Ware individual from the Baltic region.
corded_ware_baltic.paper: Allentoft et al. 2015 - Population genomics of Bronze Age Eurasia

hallstatt_celtic.name: Hallstatt Celtic (VK541)
hallstatt_celtic.description: Individual from the Hallstatt salt mines, the type site for early Celtic/Iron Age culture.
hallstatt_celtic.significance: Representative of the Celtic peoples who dominated Iron Age Europe.
hallstatt_celtic.paper: Margaryan et al. 2020 - Population genomics of the Viking world

iron_age_britain.name: Iron Age Britain (I2460)
iron_age_britain.description: Iron Age Briton from eastern England, genetically ancestral to modern British populations.
iron_age_britain.paper: Schiffels et al. 2016 - Iron Age and Anglo-Saxon genomes from East England

roman_britain.name: Roman Britain (3DRIF-26)
roman_britain.description: Individual from Roman York, showing genetic diversity of the Roman Empire's reach.
roman_britain.significance: Demonstrates the cosmopolitan nature of Roman Britain.
roman_britain.paper: Martiniano et al. 2016 - Genomic signals of migration and continuity in Britain before the Anglo-Saxons

anglo_saxon_eastry.name: Anglo-Saxon Eastry (EAS)
anglo_saxon_eastry.description: Anglo-Saxon migrant from Kent, showing Continental Germanic ancestry.
anglo_saxon_eastry.significance: Represents the Germanic migrations that transformed post-Roman Britain.

viking_denmark.name: Viking Denmark (VK1)
viking_denmark.description: Viking Age warrior from Denmark with typical Scandinavian genetic profile.
viking_denmark.significance: Representative of the Scandinavian population during the Viking expansion.

viking_sweden.name: Viking Sweden (VK417)
viking_sweden.description: Viking from the famous trading center of Birka.
viking_sweden.significance: Birka was a major Viking Age trade hub.

viking_iceland.name: Viking Iceland (VK502)
viking_iceland.description: Early Icelandic settler with mixed Scandinavian and Celtic/British ancestry.
viking_iceland.significance: Shows the mixed origins of Iceland's founding population.

viking_britain_orkney.name: Viking Orkney (VK189)
viking_britain_orkney.description: Viking Age individual from Orkney with Scandinavian ancestry.
viking_britain_orkney.significance: Orkney was under Norse control for centuries.

medieval_england.name: Medieval England (NO3423)
medieval_england.description: Medieval individual from Norwich, representative of post-Norman English population.

neolithic_britain.name: Neolithic Britain (I2657)
neolithic_britain.description: Early farmer from Britain, descended from Continental Neolithic migrants.
neolithic_britain.significance: Shows that farming was brought to Britain by migrants, not adopted locally.

funnel_beaker.name: Funnel Beaker (TRB)
funnel_beaker.description: Farmer from the Funnel Beaker culture of northern Europe.
funnel_beaker.significance: Represents the northernmost extent of Neolithic farming before Steppe migrations.
funnel_beaker.paper: Skoglund et al. 2012 - Origins and genetic legacy of Neolithic farmers and hunter-gatherers in Europe

sredny_stog.name: Sredny Stog (I6561)
sredny_stog.description: Pre-Yamnaya steppe culture that may have first domesticated the horse.
sredny_stog.significance: Ancestral to Yamnaya, early Indo-European candidate.
sredny_stog.paper: Mathieson et al. 2018 - The genomic history of southeastern Europe

afanasievo.name: Afanasievo (RISE509)
afanasievo.description: Eastern extension of Yamnaya-related peoples into Central Asia.
afanasievo.significance: Genetically almost identical to Yamnaya despite being 2000km east. Possible Tocharian ancestors.

sintashta.name: Sintashta (RISE392)
sintashta.description: Bronze Age culture known for chariot warfare and metallurgy. Possible Proto-Indo-Iranian speakers.
sintashta.significance: Ancestral to Indo-Iranian (including Vedic and Iranian) populations.

basque_iron_age.name: Iron Age Basque (I11248)
basque_iron_age.site: Alto de la Cruz, Navarra, Spain
basque_iron_age.description: Iron Age individual from the Basque region of Spain.
basque_iron_age.significance: Basques retain the highest levels of early European farmer ancestry.
basque_iron_age.paper: Olalde et al. 2019 - The genomic history of the Iberian Peninsula

roman_italy.name: Roman Italy (R35)
roman_italy.description: Roman from the Imperial period cemetery at the port of Rome.
roman_italy.significance: Shows the genetic diversity of Rome during the Empire.
roman_italy.paper: Antonio et al. 2019 - Ancient Rome: A genetic crossroads of Europe and the Mediterranean
